CONSTITUTIONAL TALKS IN LONDON


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question - [4th April]:

    That this Assembly affirms, in the name of the people of Singapore, its belief in the principle of "the basic right of peoples to governments of their own choice", as enunciated in the Washington Declaration signed by Sir Anthony Eden, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, and President Eisenhower, President of the United States of America, on the 1st of February, 1956;

    And its belief that the long term welfare of Singapore lies in close and friendly cooperation with the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth territories;

    Therefore the Assembly instructs its All-Party Delegation to the forthcoming Constitutional Talks in London to seek forthwith for Singapore the status of an independent territory within the Commonwealth, and to offer an agreement between the United Kingdom Government and the Singapore Government whereby the Government of the United Kingdom would in respect of Singapore exercise control over external defence and give guidance in foreign relations other than trade and commerce.

    Question again proposed.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on receiving notice of this motion, I pondered for some time considering what I could and should say which might be a useful and constructive contribution to what ought to be and must be an important debate. On the one hand, it would be easy and, no doubt, to many, emotionally satisfying to shout Merdeka in happy concurrence and then to sit down. On the other hand, it would be easy and cheap to dismiss this motion as a piece of eyewash because the All-Party delegation has, in fact, already given its approval to what is before us. Neither course seems to me satisfactory or helpful, for, in taking a historic decision - and indeed, it will be a historic decision for Singapore

Column: 1818

- it is as well to remember what, in fact, we are doing.

    In assessing the position of Singapore today, hovering as it does on the brink of self-government, my thoughts go back to the India of ten years ago, because, by a curious coincidence, I lived in India for the last ten years of the great country's life as a dependent territory, just as I have spent a similar period in Singapore, and several points of comparison occur to me between the India of 1946 and the Singapore of today, poised, both of them, on the eve of achieving independence.

    The first is that, whereas Britain was about to cede to the Indian peoples a vast country which had been theirs for hundreds of years before the British appeared on the scene, in the case of Singapore Her Majesty's Government is about to cede a territory for which all the communities, including the British, have had, one might say, a more or less equal share in building up. Or to put it another way: whereas nobody could seriously question that India belonged and always had belonged to the Indians as the indigenous race, there could be some legitimate argument on that score regarding Singapore.

    Secondly, that whereas India was and is a vast sub-continent measuring thousands of square miles, Singapore is a small island of 220 square miles or thereabouts which one perhaps might compare with Bombay Island in point of size and population, though it is a place of far greater strategic importance to the free world than is apparent from its size.

    Thirdly, that whereas India had considerable experience of democratic rule and of elected or partially elected provincial and local governments, in some cases going back decades before 1946, Singapore has had little, indeed insufficient, experience of this sort.

    Fourthly, that whereas India had just emerged from the Second World War in which its army had fought victoriously and with the greatest distinction, and in which it had been geared industrially to contribute immensely to the

Column: 1819

war effort, thereby having in her hands adequate strength to maintain internal security, Singapore, for various reasons, is by no means so fortunate.

    And, fifthly - and this is a point of similarity as much as of difference - whereas the problems of communal bitterness and strife were, to some extent, solved by the division of the country into Hindustan and Pakistan, no such solution is possible in a multi-racial Singapore which, though relatively peaceful today, is nevertheless dominated in numbers by the Chinese.

    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): What is wrong with that?

    Mr John Ede: I make these points for one single over-riding reason in order to make this plea - that we go forward to implement this motion, represented as we in this House are of all the major communities and voted into this House by all those communities, in all humility, conscious of the immense responsibilities we are asking to be allowed to undertake and of the considerable risks we are facing. It is an old truism that the people's character is formed by the land and the climate in which it lives. This is true of people like the English, who are what they are from their geographical position as islanders and from their rigorous climate. It is true of people like the Indians; but it is not true of the people of Singapore who have still to assimilate this land and this climate and to call it their own; in other words, to call themselves Malayans. Therein lie the risks and the responsibilities. We are seeking to govern, by ourselves, a territory for which the people as a whole have not yet and cannot have the deepest loyalties, and thus a territory which, because of its handy size, might so easily be seized by a dictator or by another form of colonial rule. Because of all these factors, which I have stated, the more thoughtful people on this island, on the one hand, deplore the emotionalism and the intemperate language which has been recklessly indulged in recent weeks, and, on the other hand, fear that

Column: 1820

the ceding to Her Majesty's Government of control over external defence is insufficient security and consider that the problem of internal security has not been squarely faced.

    Let me say this about emotional and intemperate language. Anybody who read the Congress-owned Delhi newspaper, the Hindustan Times, during the war years, would consider that some of the Members of this House had still a lot to learn regarding the art of vituperation, but I do not say that in exoneration. In a small almost parochial place like Singapore, we cannot afford inflammatory speeches. If you shout abuse in Bombay, by the time it gets to Nagpur, it sounds a little hollow, and in Calcutta, it seems merely silly. What Manchester roars today will sound like a still small voice in London tomorrow? But a Marshall thunderbolt, dropped out of the apple tree, will reverberate round the island -

    The Chief Minister: Even to Tanglin?

    Mr John Ede: - to be savoured in the clubs and in the coffee-shops till it sounds more heroic, or more despicable according to one's reactions, than it really is, and in a small island like Singapore, it encourages hatred and passion with no safety valves.

    On the question of internal security, it should be clear from what I have said that much calm thinking is needed. In this motion, we agree that we are not strong enough to defend ourselves against external aggression. But what about the Trojan Horse, the enemy within our gates? Admittedly we are not strong enough to defend our shores, but have we sufficient resources in time of riot and civil commotion, such as we have seen in 1950, in 1955, and been reminded of by the recent Kallang disturbance? At the moment, we must be honest enough to face the fact that we have not got the strength, and it seems to me that there are only three ways of overcoming this problem and of ensuring that the people of this land can go

Column: 1821

about their business knowing that their lives and property will be fully protected.

    The first possibility is to strengthen and enlarge the police force very considerably, making it more of an armed force than it is at present, but recognising that control of the police must remain with the Council of Ministers, as it does now.

    The second is that we raise and maintain our own locally recruited defence forces.

    The third is that we agree to safeguards whereby we can call upon British or other Commonwealth forces in the event of grave public disorder.

    The first possibility - a more heavily armed police force - I reject. In the hands of the wrong government, the police force could become a weapon of oppression, and Singapore a police State. Even today the police are being subjected to undesirable political pressure. That does not mean that I am against strengthening the police force on the lines along which it has been developed. It is essential that everything is done to build up and maintain the morale and esprit de corps of our police force at the highest levels. They must be incorruptible and must have such a high reputation that members of all communities will be proud to be policemen. No modern state can survive without a police force of the best standards, but, nevertheless, we must stop short of turning it into a military force.

    The second - that of raising our own defence forces - is the ideal to aim at, but it is folly to suppose that it can be done overnight or that the money can be found immediately to pay for it. The Hon. the Chief Minister has stated that the Government is attempting to raise a Singapore battalion by April 1957. This is as unrealistic as so many of the present Government's pronouncements. A normal infantry battalion consists of about 800 men, of whom 600 bayonets are for effective strength and 200 to man and maintain the vehicles to transport them and so on. In the event of island-wide disturbance, a single battalion would soon be swallowed up and

Column: 1822

lost. Experts naturally differ, but I think that the expert opinion given to me, which states that five battalions would be needed as an adequate protective force, making up a mixed brigade of infantry, armoured cars, signals, engineers and so on, should be heeded. How otherwise would the island be adequately protected in an emergency; the power-station and the water supply maintained and manned; the petrol supply to essential vehicles ensured; and the petrol dumps guarded and so on? I am not exaggerating when I say that one modern battalion costs £1 million to equip, and five battalions will therefore cost us something like $50 millions - money which we have not got, quite apart from the fact that it will take a number of years to raise and train and officer this force of 4,000 men to the proper pitch of efficiency. And if it will cost $50 millions to equip, what will it cost to maintain from year to year? This therefore has to be rejected as an immediate solution, and indeed the Government has already ruled it out by cutting down on defence in the 1956 Estimates. The P.A.P. may pooh-pooh these details as alarmist and bellicose, but the hon. Members opposite know very well that the Communist menace is such that we must be strong in our determination to defend ourselves and have the weapons to do it with.

    Thus, one turns to the third possibility, negotiation with Her Majesty's Government of safeguards whereby we can call upon British or other Commonwealth forces in the event of grave public disorder. That, for the time being, is the only solution until we can build up our own resources or until a link with the Federation changes the perspective. The Liberal-Socialists see no alternative to this as a practical solution and will in no circumstances accept anything less. If a Defence Council, consisting of Service chiefs and others on the one hand and of the Chief Minister and one or two colleagues on the other, is acceptable to the Federation, we see no reason why it cannot be acceptable here because, for one thing, the Federation and Singapore, let it not be forgotten, are fighting the same enemy -

Column: 1823

Communism. Let us remember that Merdeka means not only freedom from British rule, it means freedom to rule democratically. It also means freedom from intimidation and oppression, and the first freedom is of no value whatever without the other freedoms.

    One of the most difficult periods in a country's history is when it emerges from being ruled by a foreign power and stirs itself to take over charge of its own destiny. Once that movement has gathered momentum, let no one try to stand in its way, because it cannot be withstood. And because it is a difficult period, when tempers can fly and hateful things can be said, let us in this Assembly remember that if we can keep cool heads and reasonable words, we shall be setting an example which the country can follow.

    I wish the All-Party delegation success in its mission and may come back from London with an independent status granted which is worthy of the desires and the dignity of our people, and at the same time which, when granted, we can protect and make flourish to the greater glory of this island and to the admiration of the free world.

    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, I confess that I am a little reluctant to make a speech on this motion, but having, as it were, been spotlighted by the Chief Minister yesterday, I suppose I must say something, if only in my own defence. I must however take some comfort from the fact that I have over the past year acquired some promotion in this House, though not through intrinsic merit. In one of the early debates in this House, we were reminded by the Member for Tanjong Pagar (Mr Lee Kuan Yew) that nominated Members spoke only for themselves. So I represented nobody. Then from the lips of the Chief Minister I became the "Member for Tanglin Club" - a phoney constituency - so that, I suppose, must have been demotion. However, the appellation resulted in the House for months afterwards being treated to some fine examples of what Mr H. W. Fowler calls "worn-out humour". Then, by inference,

Column: 1824

I had some connection with the notorious and peripatetic Colonel Blimp! But now I find myself, according to the Chief Minister, "the representative of British capital interests"! I did not know I was that. I wish there was a night school that I could go to learn just what I am! But certainly that is better, though quite honestly, Sir, I do not think the cap fits. It is true that in a speech I made in this House on 22nd July, 1955, I said that I thought I might claim to speak for the British expatriate community, although I had no mandate from them to do so. My claim, Sir, may have been unjustified, and therefore I should like clearly to state that on this occasion I am speaking merely as an independent Member of the House and I would ask the House not to regard me as the mouthpiece of any community. If my views happen to coincide with some of those of my compatriots, that is all to the good - or to the bad, depending on how you look at it.

    For the most part, I find this motion quite unexceptional, couched as it is in very wide terms, and I was cheered, as I am sure many British people who read it must have been cheered, to read the reference to "close and friendly cooperation with the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth territories". I listened with very great interest indeed to the Chief Minister's speech yesterday and again found myself at one with him on a great many points. On others, I would differ but did not consider any useful purpose would be served by a non-Party Member giving his views on such matters as internal security. Nevertheless, I wish I were as certain as the Chief Minister that in the future an independent Singapore would have a viable economy. Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not intend to offer outright opposition to this motion, and accordingly I would like to explain the apparent inconsistency of having on 22nd July, 1955, said No to a motion calling for immediate self-government and my present attitude. I am afraid it does not mean that I have been wholly converted or that my views have utterly changed.

Column: 1825

In a speech made by the Chief Minister in this House on 9th February of this year, he said:

    "We have seen in a solemn moment the expression of our deepest feelings, a single - Member Party - Mr Sutherland - standing up and saying that, on behalf of the English expatriate community, he deplored our desire for immediate self-government, and he voted against it and is working against it."

The last five words are my italics. I do not understand what the Chief Minister meant by saying that I was working against self-government, but I can assure him that outside of this House I have no connection whatsoever with politics. I have been lobbied and attempts have been made to drag me into the political net, but I have always turned a deaf ear to those who importuned me. But let us examine the words of the Chief Minister - "the expression of our deepest feelings" - in its relation to "our desire for immediate self-government". It must be remembered that on 22nd July, 1955, there was no motion on the Order Paper for immediate self-government. The relevant motion referred to the determination of the people to end colonialism. It was the counter move of the then Progressive Party calling for immediate independence, which I thought very little of then, and the passing months have not changed my views; it was this gambit that forced the Chief Minister to move an amendment calling on Her Majesty's Government for the transfer of power for self-government immediately. Now be it noted that there was nothing in this amendment to define self-government as such. In my opinion, it was a trifle inchoate, yet because I did not say Aye to the motion, I came in for some contumelious criticism from all Parties. That, I suppose, is all part of the cut and thrust of debate and I doubt if, at that time, many Asian Members of this House would really have expected me pusillanimously to yield to the majority and vote for a motion that I obviously did not believe in at the time.

    Sir, I suggest that the present is a far more solemn moment and would say that I am not incapable of understanding the aspirations of the locally born and indeed in these matters my ap-

Column: 1826

proach, I think, is quite objective and I cannot, nor indeed, I am sure, would Members expect me to work myself up into a passion over them. Neither do I wish, through sheer recalcitrance like the Russians at Lake Success or Geneva, to say No on every possible occasion. The record will, in point of fact, show that only on one occasion have I voted against the Government. No, Sir, if it is indeed the wish of the people of Singapore that they should be self-governing now, -

    The Chief Minister: What do you think?

    Mr Sutherland: - I am not going to attempt to put my little spoke in their wheel. After all, in free countries, people usually get the government they deserve. For my own part, I should have thought that for sensible, free people - and the people of Singapore are free, in spite of those who talk of a century of slavery - the question was not one of desire for self-government but fitness for self-government. All this talk about primordial urges and psychiatric reasons for rebellion - a favourite line of the hon. and learned Member for Tanjong Pagar - should surely, at least to some extent, be discounted? Surely the leaders of the people could persuade them to restrain their urges for just a little longer. Last July a government which had been in office for only a few months demanded immediate self-government. How could this have been the expression of the deepest feelings of the people? I do not know whether or no those who then demanded immediate independence and immediate self-government had a mandate from their electorate to do so. I should have thought not, but I know that another school of thought is of the opinion that the elected Members of the people have carte blanche to act as they please according to their views. Be that as it may, was it so very unreasonable to challenge their fitness to govern themselves when they had had little or no experience and had not been subjected to any corroding test? At that time a very considerable measure of self-government had already been granted and had not been given a fair trial. Goaded by his opponents, the Chief Minister took a line

Column: 1827

which some people, including me, believed was not in the best interests of Singapore. Did not the Chief Minister very recently say that twelve months ago he and his Ministers knew nothing about self-government? He said it at a time when he was praising the men around him. I submit, Sir, that if he did not know anything about government twelve months ago, he could not have known a great deal about it eight months ago. I think I could guess fairly accurately when the people of Singapore first began to desire self-government. But when, I wonder, did they "graduate" to self-governing status? Was it in 1900, 1939, 1946, or was it just last year? Is there a faint possibility that the proponents of immediate self-government could be wrong and that a further period of tutelage is necessary? Would the British Government gain so very much were it to postpone the granting of self-government for a relatively short period? Could they not be acting in the very best interests of the people and not, as has been suggested, be making a last ditch stand in their own interests? Sir, the point may be academic and these questions rhetorical, for if it is simply a question of kicking out the colonial power now, the people will demand it, however complicated the issue may be, involving as it does the future of this great trading post which also happens to be a Gibraltar for the defence of the free peoples of South-East Asia. I have been reassured to hear the Chief Minister saying on a recent occasion that he does not want to kick the British into the sea. But what of his Yanko dancing opponents of the future? He might find that he himself needed swimming lessons.

    Sir, I read recently the following in the Chinese Press, in translation, of course:

    "Britain should understand that since it is impossible to restore the pre-war system of colonialism, she might as well generously and immediately promise the people of this country independence. Moreover, our claim is only for independence in the first stage. In effect, it is only complete internal self-government with external defence and external relations still remaining in the hands of Britain."

Column: 1828



    I think, Sir, that perhaps for "promise" we should read "grant" for I can hardly believe that a promise would satisfy those who are crying for independence. For the rest, the writer need not worry. Britain understands the position very well The problem, of course, is when, in the best interests of the people, should the transfer of power be made.

    Sir, I am every bit as anti-Communist as the Chief Minister, and I can comprehend fully what he is driving at in his argument that any putting of the clock back would be disastrous. I wish I had heard all that the seconder of the motion said in his speech so that I could correlate it to the Chief Minister's, but unfortunately he spoke over the microphone most of the time and a great deal of what he said was lost to me, in spite of my proximity. I know that another member of the P.A.P., according to the vernacular Press, said at a recent rally that they should be friendly with the British. If that was sincerely said, I am mighty glad to hear it.

    Sir, I note that certain Chinese newspapers now refer to the "colonialists" (and the term does not only include expatriates) as if they were a formidable section of the community opposed to immediate self-rule. What do these colonialists feel? I do not know, Sir, precisely, but I do know that it is utter rubbish to talk about them as traitors. One thing emerges quite clearly from the Merdeka campaign, and that is, that there are very many people in this island not in favour of immediate self-government. For all I know, the numbers may run into hundreds of thousands.

    Sir, what of the overseas British in Singapore? Heaven forbid that I should speak for them again, but this is the position as I see it. The British community here is not keen on the British Government relinquishing its authority immediately, but it looks as if they must take a chance and do so. A point frequently forgotten by the present Government is that the local British community have, up to last year, been associated with every step towards self-government.

Column: 1829



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Oh, come, come!

    Mr Sutherland: The overseas British here - I am not speaking of the Government officials - are part of the whole that is Singapore. They have been here since the time of Raffles and have a local as well as a national outlook. They have not in the past hesitated to criticise the Colonial Office if it were sought to introduce measures which might prove unpopular.

    The Chief Minister: To capital.

    Mr Sutherland: Quite naturally, in view of the events of the past year, some of them have doubts as to the efficiency of self-government tomorrow, while others are alarmed at the speed at which changes are taking place. Why? Because they are convinced that for Singapore to maintain its position as a trading centre second to none in South-East Asia, it must have security and stability. In that connection, Mr Speaker, I am sure that all sections of the business community would welcome an assurance from the Government that, in not requiring guidance from the United Kingdom Government in matters of trade and commerce, no thought has been taken of leaving the Sterling area.

    The Member for Tanjong Pagar said yesterday that so much had happened in the last year that he felt as if decades, instead of months, had passed, or words to that effect. How true! The passing of time, however, has not lessened his hostility to the colonial power, but the Chief Minister, I was glad to note, was much more moderate in his views. I did not feel quite so badly as I did on previous occasions when I found myself murmuring to myself - "Truly the sins of the fathers are visited on the children unto the third and fourth generations" - and thank God I have not got any!

    The Chief Minister: Confession is good for the soul!

    Mr Sutherland: Sir, I am on record in the local Hansard as having said on several occasions that I was not opposed to self-government when the country was ready for it, and I can assure the Chief

Column: 1830

Minister that I associate myself with the views of those business men who have written to him when they say, "We will co-operate with the Government on the basis of whatever decision may be reached in the London talks." I will indeed, Sir, wholeheartedly.

    I regret that I have neither the wit nor the competence to deal adequately with all that was said in the two speeches yesterday; but in conclusion I would express my regret that I cannot say Aye to this motion, involving, as it does, radical alterations to the constitution under which I was appointed a nominated Member of this Assembly, and I think, therefore, that the correct and proper course for me to take is to abstain.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the one responsible for starting the Merdeka bail rolling in this House - a move or a gamble in which the hon. Mr Sutherland has not forgiven me and may yet cancel my overdraft at his bank, I and my Party want to make it clear what we stand for. In the main, we agree with what the Chief Minister said yesterday except on the question of internal security. We particularly agree with him when he said that provision must be made to look after the minority interests. Indeed, it is the duty of every government and every political Party to look after small sections of the people who may not have adequate representation in this House. We are glad also to see the stand of the Member for Tanjong Pagar when he seconded the motion. He made it quite clear that he was doing so not because of choice, but because it could be used for something else - as a stepping - stone to something bigger and better. We know what he stands for and what he wants. His aim now is to down British colonialism. When that bogey is finished, another one will be created, and so on, until this form of government will be changed by another so-called democratic government of his, which, I am quite sure, is unknown in the free world today.

Column: 1831



    We realise that you can put back the hands of a clock, but you cannot put back the march of time. The pace has been set for colonies in Asia and Africa to be independent, and we have to follow; and the pace has been quickened by the very successful mission of the Federation to London a few months ago.

    Luckily for us we do not have to fight, nor indeed, threaten or shout for independence. We have been invited by the Government of the United Kingdom to a conference this month to discuss in a friendly manner our request to be master of our own fate in the light of a year's working of the present constitution. This invitation we have accepted, and it is for us now to examine our assets and liabilities accrued during the year. Frankly, I must admit the balance sheet is not a very encouraging one. We have passed legislation for improving the working conditions of a section of the people, but on the other hand, we have had nearly 300 strikes, one riot, one near riot, and an increase in crime, particularly that organised by gangsters, such as extortion and kidnapping.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: What is your worry?

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Well, they came from your area!

    The Chief Minister: And they are directed at the Progressives!

    Mr Speaker: Order, please.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: The tempo of public business, due to uncertainty in the future of this service, has slowed down considerably. There has been no increase in the number of factories, but unemployment is increasing.

    What happened at the Kallang Rally on Sunday, 18th March, has caused great concern, not only in the minds of people like ourselves in this Assembly, but also of the small people who frequent the coffee-shops and hawkers' stalls-except, of course, those who shout Merdeka with clenched fists and

Column: 1832

turned the rally into a riot, the only provocation being, from what I could see, a few songs, a few dances, and a few drops of rain. If such disorder can happen when the Party concerned had a hand in organising the rally and the leaders did try their best to quieten the crowd, what could not happen at uncontrolled gatherings? The Chief Minister has tried to make this incident a minor one. It was a minor one only because of the magnificent manner in which the police handled the situation - with firmness and with restraint.

    There is talk in the coffee-shops that, under such circumstances, only hooligans and gangsters would benefit from Merdeka - a Merdeka conceived in hatred, bred in strikes, and ruled by mobs and gangsters.
